Upgrade or Replace RAM

Upgrade or Replace RAM

This guide walks through upgrading or replacing the RAM in a desktop or laptop — with clear, tweakable steps and placeholder images you can replace with real photos.

  • Estimated time: 10–30 minutes
  • Difficulty: Easy–Medium (depending on device)
  • What you need: Screwdriver (if applicable), compatible RAM modules, antistatic precautions

Before you start — Safety

  1. Shut down and unplug the machine.
  2. Ground yourself (antistatic wrist strap or touch metal chassis).
  3. Work on a clean, flat surface with good light.

Steps

Below is a concise set of steps. The page layout renders these as a “Quick Steps” block above the full article. You can edit the steps frontmatter to customise titles, descriptions, and images.

Detailed procedure

1 — Identify existing RAM and slots

Open the case or access panel and note the number of modules and free slots. Look for labels on the modules for DDR generation and speed.

2 — Choose compatible replacements

Match the DDR generation (for example DDR4), the form factor (DIMM or SODIMM), and a similar or higher speed. For best results, buy from a single kit if using multiple modules.

3 — Install the modules

If replacing modules: gently press out the side clips and remove the sticks. Align the notch and press the new module straight down until clips engage.

4 — Boot and verify

Power on and enter BIOS/UEFI to verify the new capacity and frequency. In the OS, check system info or use memory tests (e.g., MemTest86) if you want to validate stability.

Customisation notes

  • Replace the heroImage and steps[*].image paths with real photos in public/assets/.
  • Add or remove steps in frontmatter — the layout will render them automatically.

If you’d like, I can replace the placeholder SVGs with real device photos, or add a simple table showing common DDR speeds and part numbers.
